lg.l: Revd Sir
I really am sorry that you are fallnfallen out with the
Spiritual World Especially if I should have to answer for it
I feel very sorry that your Ideas & Mine on Moral
Painting differ so much as to have made you angry with
my method of Study. If I am wrong I am wrong in good
company. I had hoped your plan comprehended All Species'
of this Art & Especially that you would not reject that Species '
which gives Existence to Every Other. namely Visions of EternityBentley (Writings volume 2, page 1526) reads “Visions” as “visions”.
You say that I want somebody to Elucidate my Ideas. But you
ought to know that What is Grand is necessarily obscure to
Weak men. That which can be made Explicit to the Idiot is not
worth my care. The wisest of the Ancients considerdconsidered what is not
too Explicit as the fittest for Instruction because it rouzesrouses the
faculties to act. I name Moses Solomon Esop Homer Plato
But as you have favordfavoredfavoured me with your remarks on my Design
permit me in return to defend it against a mistaken one, WhichBentley (Writings volume 2, page 1526), Erdman (page 702) and Keynes (Letters, page 8) read “Which” as “which”.
is. That I have supposed Malevolence without a Cause. _ Is
not Merit in one a Cause of Envy in anothter & Serenity &Blake appears to have written a second "t" over the poorly formed initial "t" and part of the "h" in the word "another".
Happiness & Beauty a Cause of Malevolence. But Want of
Money & the Distress of A Thief can never be alledged as the CauseBentley (Writings volume 2, page 1526) reads “Distress” as “Distross”.

of his Thievery. for many honest people endure greater hardBentley (Writings volume 2, page 1526) and Keynes (Letters, page 8) read "Thievery" as "Thieving". Keynes reads the words split between lines 22 and 23, “hard ships”, as a single word, “hardships”.
ships with Fortitude. We must therefore seek the Cause else whereErdman (page 702) and Keynes read “else where” as “elsewhere”.
than in want of Money for that is the Misers passion not the Thiefs

lg.l: I have therefore proved your Reasonings Ill proportiondproportioned which youBentley (Writings volume 2, page 1526) reads "proportiond" as "proportioned".
can never prove my figures to be. they are those of Michael AngeloMichelangeloErdman (page 702) reads “they” as “They”.
RafaelRaphael & the Antique & of the best living Models. I percieveperceive
that your Eye is perverted by Caricature Prints. which oughtErdman (page 702) suggests that an "s" was erased after the word Eye.
not to abound so much as they do. Fun I love but too much Fun
is of all things the most loathsomloathsome. Mirth is better than Fun & Hap
piness is better than Mirth. I feel that a Man may be happy in
This World. And I know that This World Is a World of ImaginationKeynes (Letters, page 9) reads "Imagination" as “IMAGINATION”.
& Vision I see Every thing I paint In This World. but Every body
does not see alike. To the Eyes of a Miser a Guinea is more beautiful
than the Sun & a bag worn with the use of Money has more beautiful
proportions than a Vine filled with Grapes. The tree which moves some
to tears of joy is in the Eyes of others only a Green thing that stands
in the way. Some See Nature all Ridicule & Deformity & by these
I shall not regulate my proportions. & Some Scarce see Nature at all
But to the Eyes of the Man of Imagination Nature is Imagination itself
As a Man is So he Sees. aAs the Eye is formed such are its PowersErdman (page 702) and Keynes (Letters, page 9) read “Man” as “man”.
You certainly Mistake when you say that the Visions of Fancy are
not to be found in This World. To Me This World is all One
continued Vision of Fancy or Imagination & I feel FlatterdFlattered
when I am told So. What is it Sets Homer Virgil & MiltonKeynes (Letters, page 9) reads "Sets" as "sets".
in so high a rank of Art. Why is the Bible more Entertaining
& Instructive than any other book. Is it not because they are
addressed to the Imagination which is Spiritual Sensation & but
mediately to the Understanding or Reason Such is True Painting

lg.l: and such ^ alone valued by the Greeks & the best modern Artists. Consider
what Lord Bacon says "Sense sends over to Imagination before Reason
have judged & Reason sends over to Imagination before the Decree can be
acted".See AdvancemtAdvancement of Learning Part 2 P 47 of first Edition
But I am happy to find a Great Majority of Fellow Mortals who
can Elucidate My Visions & Particularly they have been Elucidated by
Children who have taken a greater delight in contemplating my Pictures
than I even hoped. Neither Youth nor Childhood is Folly or Incapacity
Some Children are Fools & so are Some Old Men. But There is a vastErdman (page 703) and Keynes (Letters, page 9) read "Some" as "some".
Majority on the side of Imagination or Spiritual SensationBentley (Writings volume 2, page 1527) reads “side” as “Side”.
To Engrave after another Painter is infinitely more laborious than
to Engrave ones own Inventions. And of the Size you require my priceKeynes (Letters, page 10) reads "Size" as "size".
has been Thirty Guineas & I cannot afford to do it for less. I had Twelve

for the Head I sent you as a Specimen. but after my own designs I could For "the Head", Keynes (Letters, page 10) suggests either Blake's frontispiece to Leonard Euler's Elements of Algebra (1797) or the portrait of Wright of Derby in the Monthly Magazine (1798). Another possibility is the separate plate of Edmund Pitts, which is uncertainly dated but possibly prior to 1799 (see Essick, pages 178-80); the reference to “Chalk Engraving” would be relevant to the Pitts portrait, a stipple in what could be called a “Chalk” manner. One other possibility is the portrait of John Brown in his Elements of Medicine (1795).
do at least Six times the quantity of labour in the same time which will
account for the difference of price as also that Chalk Engraving is at least
Six times as laborious as Aqua tinta. I have no objection to Engraving afterErdman (page 703) and Keynes (Letters, page 10) read "Six” as “six”.
another Artist. Engraving is the profession I was apprenticed to. & should Bentley (Writings volume 2, page 1527) and Keynes (Letters, page 10) read "should" as "Should".
never have attempted to live by any thing else. If orders had not come
in for my Designs & Paintings which I have the pleasure to tell you
are Increasing Every Day. Thus If I am a Painter it is not to be
attributed to Seeking after. But I am contented whether I live by
Painting or Engraving
I am Revd Sir Your very obedient ServantKeynes (Letters, page 10) reads "Your" as "your". Erdman (page 703) and Keynes read "Servant" as "servant".
13 Hercules Buildings
William Blake
Lambeth
August 23. 1799
